news politics spring-statement---big-"Martin Lewis warns Brits may have to choose between ‘starving or freezing’ByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsThe biggest cost-of-living crisis for decades is hitting Brits - and most of it hasn’t even started yet.As Rishi Sunak delivers his  Spring Statement tomorrow, pleas are mounting to help the millions of Brits who could soon have to choose between food and fuel.Energy bills, National Insurance and inflation are all surging in April, outstripping below-inflation benefit, pension and wage rises. Meanwhile tax and student loan repayment thresholds are being frozen in a ‘ stealth tax ’ squeeze on the cost of living.  The Mirror understands officials are braced for inflation to peak above % this Spring, with formal forecasts due to be produced tomorrow.Chancellor Rishi Sunak is considering cutting fuel duty by p a litre and is said to have looked at raising the National Insurance threshold, to take some of the lowest-paid Brits out of the soon-to-be-hiked tax.But heaposs resisting any bigger action like axing the NI hike entirely - or raising pensions or benefits beyond .%. Money Saving Expert Martin Lewis warned on Sunday: “I am virtually out of tools to help people now.  “It’s not something money management can fix. It’s not something for those in the lowest incomes, telling them to cut their bills will work. “We need political intervention.” So as we wait for Tory Rishi Sunak to deliver any help, let’s look at the biggest cost-of-living hikes he needs to deal with - and the dates they’ll hit. InflationDATE: NOWUK CPI inflation has already hit .%, raising the cost of food, energy and transport rises at the fastest for three decades.The war between oil giant Russia and wheat-producing Ukraine is now making this worse, with officials now braced for inflation to peak above % in April.It will mean the same pound in your pocket buys you less in bread or fuel, and tightens business margins to the point where firms could go bust. The Resolution Foundation expects inflation to remain high for most of this year and still be above % in September - a level not seen since the early s.  Interest ratesDATE: NOW Last week the Bank of England increased interest rates to .%, despite warnings it would “crush” households already drowning in the cost of living crisis.The Bank took the move to slow the economy down and cool soaring inflation . Governor Andrew Bailey recently appealed to workers not to ask for big pay rises, as that fuels inflation further. But it will mean new mortgage rates become more expensive, and inflicts an overnight rise to monthly payments for people on standard iable rates. Petrol pricesDATE: NOWPetrol prices have hit record highs due to Russia’s war in Ukraine, leading Chancellor Rishi Sunak to hint he’ll temporarily cut fuel duty.The average price of petrol reached .p a litre while diesel rose to .p a litre Sunday before last.A month earlier they averaged .p and .p a litre respectively. A family car with a typical -litre tank is now paying £.p to fill up compared to £. a year earlier.But Labour warned even a rumoured p-a-litre cut would make a dference of only a couple of quid to a family tank.And Mr Sunak would face pressure to make any cut permanent, despite Tories having frozen the duty for  years already while raising taxes on everything .Energy billsDATE: April The energy price cap will increase to a record £,-a-year for a typical household following soaring gas prices. Around million Brits on iable tarfs will be hit with a £ rise to the average annual bill overnight on April . Those on fixed tarfs will be hit by rises when their fixed-rate period ends. A second hike that could be just as big or even worse is expected on October . Rishi Sunak has announced plans to help, which include people living in bands A to D getting £ discount on their council tax in England, and a £ rebate off energy bills in October.But Labour has branded him the loan shark Chancellor as the rebate is effectively a loan which will need to be repaid over five years. Tory MPs say he must go further - for instance by increasing the £ discount or £ loan, or delaying repayments. But he was reluctant to announce help before April .  National Insurance riseDATE: April A £bn rise in National Insurance will hit working people as the Treasury looks to cut Covid backlogs in the NHS and begin funding social care.Employees will pay .p more in the pound on earnings above £, a year, a rise from % to .%. This earnings threshold has risen since last year, but only by .% - less than inflation. The Lib Dems brand this a stealth tax that makes Brits pay £ more.Those supportive of Boris Johnson argue the levy is progressive as the wealthier pay more.But Tory backbenchers hostile to new taxes baulk at the plans as the tax burden hits its highest in decades. While Rishi Sunak is unlikely to scrap the rise completely, there are claims he could change the earnings threshold - for instance, aligning it with income tax . Income tax ‘stealth tax’DATE: April Rishi Sunak chose to freeze income tax thresholds at a time when inflation is climbing at frightening speed. Youaposll have to carry on paying % on earnings over £,, and % on earnings over £, - just like this year. According to the Commons library, more than a million more people will be paying a higher rate of income tax by . And that was analysed before the latest rises in inflation. The IFS think tank now warns it’s a £.bn ‘stealth tax’, two and a half times bigger than first thought.  Real terms cuts to pay - including for NHS and teachersDATE: April Inflation means many planned rises to public sector wages - which are due every April - will be wiped out by rising prices. At this rate workers will need a rise of % to % just to keep up with rising prices, but the government is resisting these. Ministers have already spelt out plans to raise salaries for experienced teachers by only % in  . Health unions have also blasted plans to offer NHS staff in England a “miserly” % hike. The Royal College of Nursing is demanding % above inflation.  Council tax riseDATE: April  Most of England’s families will be hit with a Council Tax rise of % or more next Friday, Mirror research reveals. Of  councils that run social care, the Mirror found  were planning rises of .% - the maximum normally allowed this year. And a further  planned rises higher than .%, by using allowances that were unused in previous years. Now of course, most people’s council tax will be lower than last year due to the £ discount for Band A-D homes in England. But there are two big catches. First, that £ is meant to pay for energy bills - not absorbing the cost of a tax rise. In Rutland a Band D bill will go up by £, wiping out much of the £ discount. Second, the £ is a one-off. Next Spring, you’ll suddenly feel the force of not just this year’s rise but also the April  rise at the same time.Search for your council tax rise by postcode by following the link below. Covid testsDATE: April From April  the vast majority of people must paythey want a Covid lateral flow test - eventhey have a cough and fever. No has said spending £bn a month on free tests is not an effective use of taxpayers’ money at this point. This prompted a furious row with Labour, some medics and the Scottish and Welsh governments.Asymptomatic tests for NHS workers will be made available but not routinely, only as a surge effort where thereaposs an outbreak. But they will be available for care home residents. Exact lists of those eligible are being drawn up.Boots is preparing to charge £ for a pack of five. Student loans aposstealth taxaposDATE: April Millions will be forced to pay more on their student loans under what has been branded a “stealth tax rise”. Student loan repayment thresholds will be frozen from April  after plans to raise them by .% were scrapped. That means graduates will have to shell out more of their disposable income as wages and prices rise with inflation. The respected Institute for Fiscal Studies warned the freeze will cost £k earners £ a year more than they expected. IFS senior economist Ben Waltmann said it was “a further hit to real incomes”, adding it “effectively constitutes a tax rise by stealth on graduates with middling earnings.” It gets worse further in the future. Students starting university next year will begin paying off their loans when they earn more than £, - down from the existing £,-a-year threshold. And theof time to repay their debt will be extended to  years, up from . The IFS said this will leave poorer graduates paying £, more over their letimes.  Real terms cut to welfare benefitsDATE: April  Benefits will rise by .%, as little as £. a month on the rate of Universal Credit.Tory MPs pushed through the plans earlier this year - saying it was in line with inflation. But it’s only in line with what inflation was last September, before prices began to soar at an alarming rate. Many are warning that this will severely exacerbate the cost-of-living crisis for those who are struggling the most, with food bank use climbing. The Resolution Foundation has urged Rishi Sunak to raise benefits more generously as an urgent priority, ahead of any decision to cancel the National Insurance rise. Pensions are being cut in real terms - before rising next yearDATE: April Pensions could rise by more than % next April after the Tory DWP chief promised to bring back the triple lock - despite soaring inflation. Therese Coffey suspended the triple lock - a solemn manesto pledge - for one year in   because post-Covid wages were bouncing back in an “anomaly”.That sparked fury as it meant the state pension will rise by only .% next month, less than inflation. That is a real-terms cut of £ to Britain’s million pensioners, Shadow DWP chief Jon Ashworth said.But Ms Coffey said the triple lock wouldin   as promised. That could lead to a rise of .%, experts predict. A real-terms cut to childcare helpDATE: NOWPoor parents will be hit hard by April’s cost-of-living crisis as Tory ministers refuse to raise a crucial childcare allowance - despite soaring inflation. Parents on Universal Credit can claim back % of childcare costs, but only up to a £.-a-month cap - which has not changed since  and is not rising in April. Campaigner and working mum to a four-year-old and Gemma Widdowfield, , told MPs: “We’re all in the midst of a cost-of-living crisis. £.bn of help to support Brits with the biggest cost of living crisis since records began in the s.But critics say his aposAlice in Wonderlandapos Spring Statement wonapost touch the sides as a series of price rises come down the track next month. Their benefits will rise by just .% for the coming financial year. Their cost of living could well rise by %.”The Chancellor announced cuts to fuel duty and National Insurance - the latter being a tax heaposs hiking at exactly the same time.He also promised to cut income tax from p to p in the pound in April , just in time for a general election. After  years of Tory government, Britain needs a pay rise. But this Chancellor has no plan to get wages rising and give working people long-term financial security.”  Tax Justice UK Executive Director, Robert Palmer, said: “The Chancellor used his Spring Statement to campaign for an election in two years, while millions wonder what theyaposll have to eat in two days.” Michael Clarke of debt charity Turnus said: “We’re already hearing how many household budgets simply can’t stretch anymore. he next  months will result in thousands of people facing impossible choices between keeping a roof over their heads or feeding their children to survive.” Here are some of the biggest crises coming down the track to you - and what,anything, Rishi Sunak announced to help.InflationDATE: NOW WHATaposS HAPPENING:UK CPI inflation hit .% in February. The Budget watchdog now says itaposll rocket to an average of .% this year - and could peak at nearly % thanks to the Ukraine-Russia war.That -year high will mean the pound in your pocket buys you less in bread or fuel, and tightens business margins to the point firms could go bust. It means real household disposable income set to fall .% this year - the biggest since records began in .WHAT SUNAK ANNOUNCED:The Chancellor cut fuel duty, raised National Insurance thresholds and increased a Household Support Fund in what the Treasury claimed was £.bn of help. But it wonapost help the poorestand he admitted he canapost stop the tide of inflation. Mr Sunak said: “The OBR have not accounted for the full impacts go the war in Ukraine and we should be prepared for the economy and public finances to worsen - potentially signicantly”.The IFS think tank warned even with everything put together, a middle earner on £, can still expect to be £ worse off this year than last year.  Interest ratesDATE: NOW WHATaposS HAPPENING:Last week the Bank of England increased interest rates to .%, despite warnings it would “crush” households already drowning in the cost of living crisis.The Bank took the move to slow the economy down and cool soaring inflation . Governor Andrew Bailey recently appealed to workers not to ask for big pay rises, as that fuels inflation further. But it will mean new mortgage rates become more expensive, and inflicts an overnight rise to monthly payments for people on standard iable rates. WHAT SUNAK ANNOUNCED:The Chancellor had his hands tied on this one as interest rates are decided independently by the Bank of England.There was no new help for homeowners in the Spring Statement, apart from knocking the % VAT off green home improvements like solar , insulation and heat pumps. Meanwhile the Bank rate rise has knocked £bn off the public finances by making borrowing more expensive, wiping out the National Insurance rise in one fell swoop. Petrol pricesDATE: NOW WHATaposS HAPPENING:Petrol prices have hit record highs due to Russia ’s war in Ukraine. The average price of petrol reached .p a litre while diesel rose to .p a litre Sunday before last.A month earlier they averaged .p and .p a litre respectively. A family car with a typical -litre tank is now paying £.p to fill up compared to £. a year earlier. WHAT SUNAK ANNOUNCED:Fuel duty will be cut by p a litre from pm tonight until March .The Chancellor said itaposs the biggest cut ever and the Treasury boasted the fuel duty cut, along with a freeze already planned, will save the average van driver around £ this year - or £, for the average haulier. But it will still only knock around £ off a -litre tank for a family car. The Resolution Foundation said it will save the typical driving households £ a year, but evenpassed on in full by garages, it will only reverse % of the increase in pump prices over the past year.Energy billsDATE: April  WHATaposS HAPPENING:The energy price cap will increase to a record £,-a-year for a typical household. Around million Brits on iable tarfs will be hit with a £ rise to the average annual bill overnight on April .A second hike that could be just as big or even worse is expected on October .WHAT SUNAK ANNOUNCED: Rishi Sunak previously announced plans to help, which include people living in bands A to D getting £ discount on their council tax in England, and a £ repayable rebate off energy bills in October.But he announced no new cash help in the Spring Statement today - despite speculation he was going to raise the £ or delay the date to start repaying it beyond April .  National Insurance riseDATE: April  WHATaposS HAPPENING: A £bn rise in National Insurance will hit working people as the Treasury looks to cut Covid backlogs in the NHS and begin funding social care.Employees will pay .p more in the pound on earnings above the threshold, a rise from % to .%.WHAT SUNAK ANNOUNCED:Mr Sunak raised the threshold at which workers start paying National Insurance by £, to £, - claiming itaposd save Brits up to £ a year.Of all the cost of living rises facing Brits this is the one Rishi Sunak came closest to sorting out today. But this doesnapost factor in a . percentage point rise in the same tax . This will cut into the £ saving, and outstrip it entirely for anyone earning over £, a year.Shadow Chancellor Rachel Reeves has accused Rishi Sunak of “making an historic mistake” by failing to scrap a tax hike on jobs, warning families will “endure signicant hardship” within days.Officials are also confident that inflation is so high, there will still be more National Insurance coming in overall - despite thresholds being raised today. Income tax ‘stealth tax’DATE: April  WHATaposS HAPPENING:Rishi Sunak chose to freeze income tax thresholds at a time when inflation is climbing at frightening speed. Youaposll have to carry on paying % on earnings over £,, and % on earnings over £, - just like this year.According to the Commons library, more than a million more people will be paying a higher rate of income tax by . The IFS think tank now warns it’s a £.bn ‘stealth tax’, two and a half times bigger than first thought. WHAT SUNAK ANNOUNCED:Rishi Sunak announced no changes to the thresholds today despite a campaign to do so. The National Insurance thresholds are more generousbut income tax remain frozen.The IFS said as a result, almost all workers will be paying more tax on their earnings in  than they would have been - even when todayaposs tax cuts are taken into account. Real terms cuts to pay - including for NHS and teachersDATE: April  WHATaposS HAPPENING:Inflation means many planned rises to public sector wages - which are due every April - will be wiped out by rising prices.Ministers have already spelt out plans to raise salaries for experienced teachers by only % in  . Health unions have also blasted plans to offer NHS staff in England a “miserly” % hike. The Royal College of Nursing is demanding % above inflation.WHAT SUNAK ANNOUNCED:The Chancellor announced no extra cash for public sector wage rises. They are already having to be funded out of departmentsapos existing budgets - those did not rise today.Royal College of Nursing General Secretary Pat Cullen said: “Nursing feel extremely short-changed by this statement. The cost-of-living crisis means some are having to choose between filling up their cars and feeding their children. Todayaposs fuel measures are not enough to stop nursing staff subsidising the NHS when they fill up their car.  Council tax riseDATE: April  WHATaposS HAPPENING:Most of England’s families will be hit with the maximum Council Tax next Friday, Mirror research reveals. Of  councils that run social care, the Mirror found  were planning rises of .% or higher.Now of course, most people’s council tax will be lower than last year due to the £ discount for Band A-D homes in England. But there are two big catches. First, that £ is meant to pay for energy bills - not absorbing the cost of a tax rise. In Rutland a Band D bill will go up by £, wiping out much of the £ discount. WHAT SUNAK ANNOUNCED:The Chancellor announced no changes to the council tax bills and no increase to the £. Councils were however given another £million to help the hardest-up families via the Household Support Fund - doubling it to £bn.The Local Government Association said the cash was welcome, but warned pressure on councils is signicant andthis continued pressure cannot be met by council tax rises alone - suggesting more local cuts are in the offing. WHAT SUNAK ANNOUNCED: Rishi Sunak announced nothing to stop the VAT hike. UKHospitality Chief Executive Kate Nicholls said: “Locking in VAT at .% would have given hospitality businesses a major boost, and helped the sector in its ambition to lead the UK back to post-Covid prosperity.As it is, thousands of jobs could be lost, the UK will remain uncompetitive versus international rivals, and already hard-pressed consumers in the midst of a cost-of-living crisis will see price rises in their favourite pubs, bars and restaurants, further fuelling inflation. Student loans aposstealth taxaposDATE: April  WHATaposS HAPPENING:Millions will be forced to pay more on their student loans under what has been branded a “stealth tax rise”. Student loan repayment thresholds will be frozen from April  after plans to raise them by .% were scrapped.The respected Institute for Fiscal Studies warned the freeze will cost £k earners £ a year more than they expected. Quite the contrary - the small print of Budget forecasts shows the long-term changes to the student loan system will net tens of billions for the Chancellor.It will save the public finances £.bn in   and an average of £.bn a year over the following years.  Massive real-terms cut to welfare benefitsDATE: April  WHATaposS HAPPENING:Benefits will rise by .%, as little as £. a month on the rate of Universal Credit.Tory MPs pushed through the plans earlier this year - saying it was in line with inflation. But inflation has since doubled to .%. This will severely exacerbate the cost-of-living crisis for those who are struggling the most, with food bank use soaring as food prices in the supermarket rise by a predicted %.WHAT SUNAK ANNOUNCED:The Chancellor announced no changes to benefits despite speculation he could tweak work allowances in Universal Credit.His allies claimed he didnapost need to act again after raising work allowances and cutting the taper rate in the last Budget. But these measures only help people in work - as do most of the measures announced today, too. Once again, those who cannot work due to sickness or other reasons are left behind. That is a real-terms cut of £ to Britain’s million pensioners, Shadow DWP chief Jon Ashworth said.But Ms Coffey said the triple lock wouldin   as promised. news politics sunaks-mini-budget-sickener-living-"Spring Statement: Rishi Sunaks announcements explainedByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political EditorBen GlazeDeputy Political EditorAletha Adu:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsRishi Sunak’s mini-Budget today did little to help struggling Brits who begged him to urgently tackle the cost-of-living crisis. The Chancellor offered no support for families facing energy bill hikes of £,, gave out measly benefits rises and snubbed hard-up pensioners. Even a p cut in fuel duty only brings soaring petrol prices back to what they were last week. It comes as experts warned households face the biggest single-year fall in incomes since . Labour’s Rachel Reeves said: “The ­Chancellor does not understand the scale of the challenge.”Hard-up Brits who pinned their hopes on Rishi Sunak easing the crippling cost-of-living crisis were dealt a crushing blow today.How will the spring statement affect you  Join the discussion in the comment section The Chancellor’s Spring Statement did little to help people struggling with soaring costs and energy bills.There was nothing to boost those on benefits or pensioners, who risk being plunged further into poverty. And even a p cut in fuel duty only takes the price of petrol back to last week’s after it had already gone up by the same amount.It comes as the Office for Budget Responsibility warned families to prepare for the biggest single-year fall in household incomes since .Labour ’s Rachel Reeves said: “It’s clear the ­Chancellor does not understand the scale of the challenge.”  Mr Sunak’s overall package is targeted at the better off with those most likely to struggle faring worst. The ­Resolution ­Foundation think-tank claimed only £ in every £ announced in the ­mini-Budget would be going to the bottom half of the income ­distribution. It found the richest half of households gain £, compared to just £ for the poorest fth.People on benefits are getting a rise worth half the rate of inflation and have had Universal Credit cut by £, a year. And the Chancellor, with one eye firmly on the next election, pledged to cut income tax by p – but not until April .Institute for Fiscal Studies director Paul Johnson said: “The thing that was missing from this was anything for people on Universal Credit or state pension. That’s only going up by .% next month, when inflation may be %. So that’s going to be a big cut in living ­standards for those on the lowest incomes.”  Personal finance expert Martin Lewis warned the mini-Budget was “not going to lt that many out of the mire”.TUC General Secretary Frances O’Grady added: “In the midst of the biggest wages and bills crisis in living memory, Rishi Sunak ’s ­statement has failed ­families.“We did not get the urgent help with soaring bills that they need.” Tax Justice UK executive director, Robert Palmer, said: “The Chancellor used his statement to campaign for an election in two years, while millions wonder what they’ll have to eat in two days.” Mr Sunak increased the threshold at which people pay National Insurance to £, from July, but refused to axe the planned rise from % to .%. And his failure to lt income tax ­thresholds as wages rise creates “fiscal drag” where more people are pulled into a higher tax bracket. It means overall taxes are to hit .% of GDP – the highest burden since the late s. Official figures showed inflation would average .% this year – and could hit almost % later. The economy is f­orecast to grow by just .% this year, the OBR said – a sharp drop from its ­prediction of .%. Mr Sunak announced the ­household support fund will increase by £million for councils to distribute to those most in need. But two-thirds of Brits believe his measures will not benefit people like them much, according to a snap poll by YouGov.Asda and Sainsbury’s last night became the first retailer to pass on the cut in fuel duty, by dropping prices by p. But the RAC called the reduction in duty “something of a drop in the ocean”. Head of policy ­Nicholas Lyes said: “In reality, reducing it by p will only take prices back to where they were just over a week ago.” Key pointsFuel duty cut by p per litre with immediate effect Income tax cut by p from  People on benefits who get below-inflation rise and no extra help NI threshold increases - but so does levy itself Small boost for support via councils for poorest households No VAT on solar , heat pumps or insulation No extra money for defence Inflation could hit % this year Biggest single-year in household incomes since s. Benefits Charities have spoken of their shock that there is no extra cash for benefits. Payments are due to rise by just .% next month - despite inflation being .% and tipped to pass % later this year. Trussell Trust foodbank boss Emma Revie said: “The Chancellor has failed to create any security for people on the lowest incomes by failing to bring benefits payments in line with the true cost of living.” Child Poverty Action Group’s Sara Ogilvie said Rishi Sunak “should have increased benefits to match inflation”. She added: “He failed the children who needed him the most.” . Home Bills The Government has already announced a £ loan to every family to cut gas and electric payments from October although not until the price cap jumps %. In addition, some households get a £ council tax rebate in April. Homeowners installing solar , heat pumps, or insulation will not pay VAT. Local authorities will get another £m from April, to help vulnerable households. However, with energy bills set to reach almost £, a year from April, and again in October when the price cap rises, the extra support on offer is unlikely to go far enough. . Fuel Duty Motorists face an anxious wait to see how many petrol retailers pass on a p cut in fuel duty.The volatile oil market has sent prices soaring following Russia ’s invasion of Ukraine, with a litre of petrol yesterday averaging £.. Until pm last night that included p of duty which has now been cut.Filling up an average family car should be £ cheaper. AA president Edmund King welcomed the move, but added: “The benefit will be lost unless retailers pass it on.” Road Haulage Association executive director Rod McKenzie said “more could have been done”. . Green issues VAT of % will be scrapped on installing solar , heat pumps and insulation to tackle high energy bills and cut emissions. It will knock £ off the £, cost of fixing solar  and comes as the energy price cap rises by £ next month. Energy and Climate Intelligence Unit analyst Jess Ralston called the VAT axe “a boost for families”.Doug Parr, of Greenpeace UK, said: “Millions pay to heat homes so poorly insulated the warmth shoots right outside. Cutting VAT on insulation, solar  and heat pumps is a welcome start to ending that huge waste of energy.” . National insuranceMr Sunak decided against postponing the planned National Insurance hike from % to .%, to fund the NHS backlog and social care, despite pressure from Tory and Opposition MPs.Instead, he is raising the threshold for when people start paying contributions by £, to £, from July – a tax cut for employees of about £ a year. Mr Sunak said around % of workers – everyone earning below £, according to the Resolution Foundation – would have their tax cut by more than April’s NI rise. But millions are still facing an increase overall. . IncomeIncome tax will fall by a penny weeks before the next general election. The basic rate is being cut to p in . The £bn giveaway is worth an average £.Tim Walford-Fitzgerald, of accountancy firm HW Fisher, said: “This is a tactical move from the Chancellor. Assuming it comes into effect from April , the first payslip you will see this in will arrive at the same time as election leaflets.” Maike Currie, of Fidelity International, said: “We know the personal allowance and higher rate band thresholds have been frozen for four years, meaning more people will be pulled into higher rates.” . Defence Pleas to pump more cash into the armed forces were rebuffed despite Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. The Mirror told last week how retired top brass, Tory MPs and military experts believe extra funds are needed. Rishi Sunak was challenged by the DUP’s Sammy Wilson who said: “Surprisingly there is no mention of additional resources for defence in the face of Putin’s aggression. Why ” Mr Sunak replied: “We increased the defence budget by £billion in , the largest increase since the Cold War. It was the only department that got a four-year settlement.” . title: tories accused inaction over uk
story: Tories accused of inaction over UK drinking deaths -  years after alcohol strategyTen years ago today, David Cameron vowed to kick binge drinking to the curb and introduce minimum pricing of alcohol. Labour MP Dan Carden has urged the Government to recommit to helping victims of substance abuse Image: PAByAletha AduPolitical Correspondent:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsA record number of Brits are dying from alcohol abuse because of a decade of Tory inaction, an MP has claimed. Labour ’s Dan Carden said lives could have been savedthe Conservatives had not axed plans for the minimum pricing of alcohol. Ten years ago today, David Cameron launched the Tories aposAlcohol Strategyapos which aimed to cut the number of heavy drinkers and ease the burden on the NHS.But plans for minimum unit pricing - raising the cost of the cheapest booze - were shelved. In , there were , alcohol-specic deaths across the UK. This up .% from  when there were , alcohol-specic deaths recorded across the UK. The rise was described as “statistically signicant” by the Office for National Statistics , which published the figuresNeeds a comparative figure. What was it in  or   Four out of five those alcohol-specic deaths in  – defined as being a direct consequence of alcohol misuse – were from liver disease. On top of this, the Alcohol Health Alliancefound only one in five dependent drinkers have had access to treatment. Mr Carden renewed calls for an Independent Review of Alcohol Harm and an Alcohol Strategy. He told the Mirror: “After a decade of inaction, this is not an anniversary worth celebrating. “With record alcohol-specic deaths, rising economic and social harms, and depleted treatment services, people are rightly asking why it has taken so long for the Government to bring forward a plan to tackle alcohol harm. “We need to remove barriers to effective action, including the undue influence of corporate lobbyists on policy decisions. Government must finally put public health first. Lives depend on it.”  Sir Ian Gilmore, Chair of the AHA added: “The situation has never looked bleaker. “Deaths from alcohol are now at record highs, only one in five dependent drinkers are in treatment and alcohol causes  cancer cases every day. Meanwhile, the Alcohol Industry lines its pockets. “We need a strategy with measures to stop the incessant promotion of alcohol, give consumers information on harms, and to properly fund alcohol treatment.” Boris Johnson included plans to tackle alcohol-related crime in his -year drug strategy.In his -year drugs plan, Mr Johnson vowed to deliver world-class drug and alcohol treatment and a recovery system across England. By the end of   the Government promises to deliver at least , new high-quality drug and alcohol treatment places, a % increase on current numbers. Mr Carden has talked openly in Parliament about his battles to get support for alcohol addiction. title: tories incapable helping keep families
story: Rishi Sunak has sunk Brits living standards like a PO owner sacking galley slavesTaking more money out of peoples pay packets and bank accounts when prices are rocketing is Rishi Sunak pouring petrol on the cost of living crisisopinionByKevin MaguireAssociate editor:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsWith the insensitivity of a PO owner sacking galley slaves, Rishi Sunakaposs sunk the living standards of British families. Cometh the hour, cometh the blinkered out of touch Chancellor failing to rise to the challenge. Heaposs fiddled while household budgets are burning from searing inflation averaging .% thataposll deliver the worst cut in living standards for more than half a century. Back to the s may prove Sunakaposs prospects of succeeding Boris Johnson are hitting the rocks. Taking more money out of peopleaposs pay packets and bank accounts when prices are rocketing is the Tory Treasury pouring petrol on the cost of living crisis. This Chancellor remains a record tax raiser, upping the National Insurance threshold giving back only a little of the extra £-billion to be grabbed. Reducing fuel duty p might never be felt at the pumps and is a fraction of an increase in the price of a litre since topping p since the start of the year.And that promise of a p Income Tax cut in two years is an election bribe suggesting a contest in Autumn  or Spring . It deserves to be greeted with the same suspicion generated by PO claims the ferry firm obeys the law. The  Conservative Manesto promised NI wouldnapost go up , the pension triple-lock would continue and international aid was protected . The penny off tax also exposes the Tory lie the NI jump is a hypothecated health and social care levy when the switch emphasises itaposs really another tax rise but a little will be ed. Sunak, Johnson and Conservative ideology are the main problem. Not Covid last year, Ukraine this year or next year presumably a big boy with a stick who ran away. The Tories are proving politically, practically and ideologically incapable of helping keep families afloat. Never mind prosper. title: 10 most common covid symptoms
story: most common Covid symptoms right now – as cases surge in the UKAs Covid cases continue to surge in the UK due to the easing of restrictions and the Omicron stealth iant, we take a look at the  most common symptoms right nowRunny nose is the most common Covid symptom right now, according to the Zoe Study app Image: Ute Grabowsky Photothek Getty ImagesByAriane Sohrabi-ShirazSEO Editor:,  Mar |comments The UK’s Covid rates continue to rise, partly due to the highly infectious Omicron B. iant, also known as stealth Omicron. Other contributing factors could include the easing of coronavirus restrictions in February, and possible waning immunity from the vaccine. All age groups have been affected, including those aged over  who are due a Spring booster jab. Although those in England are no longer required by law to self isolate, the NHS is recommending people who are infected stay home to avoid spreading the virus.Here we take a look at the  most common symptoms to look out for right now. What are the most common symptoms of Covid   Keep in mind that the official list of Covid symptoms, according to the NHS, hasn’t changed. They are:High temperature A new, continuous cough Loss of smell tasteHowever, experts are still urging the government to update them, as many have reported other symptoms. Professor Tim Spector, who runs the Zoe Covid Study app, has published a list of the most common symptoms of Covid. They are:Runny noseHeadacheAny fatigue Sore throat SneezingPersistent coughHoarse voiceChills or shiversUnusual joint painsFever What to doyou test positive for Covid If you have symptoms of Covid, you should order a PCR test from the NHS website, or attend a site.This will change from April, but at the moment this is the advice you should follow.You are no longer required by law to self-isolateyou have Covid-.However, the NHS still recommends you stay at home and avoid contact with other people because this helps reduce the chance of passing Covid- on to others. You should consider staying at homeyou have any of the main symptoms of Covid- ofyou have tested positive for Covid-, which means you have the virus. Those who live in the save household as, or have had close contact with, someone who has Covid- also no longer need to self isolate. Who is eligible for Spring Covid booster jab   As of Monday, March , the NHS has started inviting eligible people to come forward for their Spring booster jabs.Anyone who qualies can now book their appointment on the NHS website, or by calling , which is free from mobile phones and landlines.The Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisationhas said that the spring booster should be offered to the most vulnerable groups in the UK. This includes people who are  and over, as well as those who are immunosuppressed and over the age of . story: Cheeky dog lucky to survive after asthma inhaler exploded in her mouthMarion Reith, a pharmacy worker from Edinburgh, was just at home when she suddenly heard a loud bang - only to discover her puppy Leia had chewed on an inhalerMarion Reiths puppy Leia chewed on an inhaler and it exploded in her mouth Image: Vets Now   SWNSByDaniel MorrowTrends WriterLucy SkouldingFreelance writer:,  Mar |comments A playful and cheeky dog was very lucky to survive after an inhaler exploded in her mouth. Marion Reith, a pharmacy worker from Edinburgh, was just at home when she suddenly heard a loud bang - only to find out her puppy Leia had chewed on an inhaler. The pharmacy worker knew the potentially lethal dangers of salbutamol which is inside an inhaler and so she rushed Leia to the Vets Now clinic in the Scottish capital, reports the Daily Record.She said: “Leia can be quite playful and she has a thing for chewing anything plastic she can get hold of. “Because of that, I’m really careful to keep my inhaler well away from Leia. It was in my handbag and I’d been looking for something and must have left it on the floor. “I’d just stepped into the kitchen when I heard this bang, and I knew right away what must have happened.“It had exploded so fiercely we had to hunt for the cylinder which had shot right across the room. “Leia was just standing there looking dazed. I work in a pharmacy and had done some training last year and had learned that the inhalers were toxic to pets.  “I knew it could shut down her organs and prove fatal, so I needed help quickly. Her heart rate was racing, and it was so worrying.” Veterinary staff admitted Leia for treatment following a thorough examination. Tests discovered Leia was suffering from cardiotoxicity and Mario faced an anxious overnight wait on the condition of her pup.  Fiona Selby, emergency vet surgeon at Vets Now Edinburgh, said: “There was evidence of cardiotoxicity and we wanted to get her heart rate down safely. “We put her on fluid and medication and, happily, over the next few hours the heart rate slowed, her potassium levels stabilised and Leia started to recover. “Inhalers can be highly dangerous and getting Leia here really quickly was vital.” Thankfully, Marion was able to pick Leia up the following morning. She is now on the mend following the traumatic episode. “She was a bit off-colour for a couple of days, but she was back to her old self after that”, Marion added. “It just shows that it only takes a moment, so do keep inhalers well away from pets and don’t delaysomething happens. story: Family who won four-bed house in prize draw now raffling it off for £ a ticketClaire Reynolds, , and Ben Binks, , have been living in a four-bedroom detached new-build in Wakefield, for the past two years but have decided to move to Spain and to have their home go to another raffle winnerClaire Reynolds, , and Ben Binks, , have been living in a four-bedroom detached new-build in Ossett, Wakefield, for the past two years Image: Yorkshire Live MEN MediaByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Mar |commentsA couple who won their family home in a raffle for just £ is raffling it off again for £. Claire Reynolds, , and Ben Binks, , have been living in a four-bedroom detached new-build in Wakefield, for the past two years. They now want to move to Spain for a warmer climate to help their four-year-old sonaposs brittle bones. The whole house is freshly decorated, with a large back garden, garage and driveway big enough for two cars. The master bedroom has its own en-suite. The winnings also include Claire and Benaposs seven-seater Range Rover Sport and Kawasaki Ninja Superbike.The couple has four children, aged , , four, and four months. Claire said: Weaposve sorted all the estate agent and legal fees and things like that so all anybody has to do is buy a ticket. We won the house in a similar raffle two years ago and have been living in it since. But my second youngest, who is four, has a health condition. He has brittle bones, so we want to move to Spain as the warmer climate will be so much better for him.  It will mean so much to us to be able to do that for him - this could make our dreams come true of starting a new le. The raffle is managed by the competitionaposs  Raffall, which ensures ticket revenue remains blocked until winners confirm receipt of their prizes. Claire and Ben won the house in a raffle for just £ two years ago when the previous owner wanted to move to Australia. The raffle is open until September  as Claire estimates they have already sold, , tickets.In , Claire and Ben Binks decided to go all in for the house and bought £ worth of tickets. They won and moved into the , property, which is less than  minutes from their current place. The organiser of the raffle, Dale Tate, had decided to put the house up for grabs having failed to find a buyer. He was overjoyed with having sold , tickets and for who won the top prize. He said at the time: The family is the most deserving family. We met them yesterday and they have been through some pretty hard times as two of their boys have got health issues and we really couldnapost have asked for a nicer family for this to happen to. They live on a council estate and donapost own their own home so this really is just a fairytale ending. title: free covid tests scaled back
story: Free Covid tests scaled back as people scramble for free kits before theyre scrappedBrits are being discouraged from ordering packs of free NHS lateral flow tests - with authorities saying most tests are needed for people considered higher riskNHS lateral flow tests are unavailable in many areas of the country Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByMartin BagotHealth and Science editorPickover Ella:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments Free Covid- tests in England are being scaled back as people scramble for free test packs while they are still available. In many areas of the country home delivery of free NHS lateral flow tests are unavailable.People trying to order are discouraged to order packs when they try and access them online. “Most tests are now needed for people at higher risk,” according to the online ordering system.“In England, most people without Covid- symptoms no longer need to take rapid lateral flow tests. “Some people still need tests to stay safe, like: NHS staff people who are at higher risk people who are visiting high-risk places.“We want to make sure tests are available for people who need them most.”  There is still confusion within the NHS as to whether tests will still be free for staff. The NHS Confederation said that workers may be forced to fork out about £ a month for teststhey have to pay themselves, as it called for clarity over the issue. The Department of Health and Social Care said that more details would be set out “shortly”. Free universal testing for the virus will come to an end on April , with free tests only being made available to the most vulnerable. Officials have previously said that the number of free tests available each day will be capped to “manage demand” as the Government scales back free testing for people in England.  The public have been encouraged not to stockpile test packs but since ministers announced the end of the free testing programme for most of the population it has been dficult for many to access them. But the UK Health Security Agencysaid that availability is refreshed regularly. A UKHSA spokesperson said: “As set out in the Living With Covid plan, from April  free tests will only be available for certain groups who are at most risk from the virus.“In preparation for this change, the gov.uk home ordering channel is asking users to only order test kitsyou’re eligible for new Covid- treatments, work or volunteer in a high-risk setting or support people who are at higher risk from Covid-.“Tests should only be ordered after you have used up any kits you already have at home.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NHSCoronavirus testing" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: man 41 who needed life
story: Man, , who needed le-saving blood transfusion died due to damaged passportChaz Carl Powell, , was due to fly home from Montego Bay in Jamaica to London Gatwick on March , but his passport was rejected by British Airways staff as it did not "match" his passport pictureChaz Carl Powell, , suffered with sickle cell anaemia and desperately needed a blood transfusion Image: MyLondon BPMByCallum CuddefordSam TrueloveNews reporter:,  Mar |commentsA man trying to fly back to London for a le-saving blood transfusion had his passport rejected by British Airways staff because he did not match his passport picture, his mum has claimed. Chaz Carl Powell had been visiting his girlfriend in Montego Bay, Jamaica but was due toas he was suffering with sickle cell anaemia. The -year-old had put on weight and grown dreads since his passport photo was taken. His passport was also slightly damaged, but his driving licence was in perfect condition. Chaz, from Camberwell, was due to have his six weekly blood transfusion as soon as he got home, but the missed flight meant he had to apply for emergency travel documents at the British Consulate instead.On March , he died of apparent organ failure after his health spiralled out of control, MyLondon reports. A British Airways said the company was saddened to hear about Chazaposs death, adding airport staff did what they could to help but the passport was too badly damaged to be considered as a valid travel document.  Chazaposs mum, Sandra Powell, , claims her son should have been let on the flight home. Sandra, a Southwark Council officer, said: I canapost talk about it, I do not even want to think about it. To know that he actually went on holiday and itaposs something he would do on a regular basis. That should never have happened, they had no right to take control of my sonaposs le. Sandra admitted she was in complete shock over her sonaposs death. The devastated mum added Chaz would drive her around whenever she needed him, so much so people thought he was my partner. Chaz was also close to his grandma and the pair always went to their hospital appointments together.  Sandra added: My mum has dementia, but when she sees all the flowers she keeps breaking down. I have to hide some of the cards so she will not read them. Sandra claims her sonaposs death was brought on by the stress of having his passport rejected. He had an arrangement for his nurse at Kings, as soon as he landed he would ring her for an appointment and come in to get his transfusion, she added. Chazaposs girlfriend Monique Allen, , reported that Chaz was complaining of stomach aches and finding it dficult to eat while he waited for new documents. He collapsed while at Spanish Town Hospital and doctors were unable to resuscitate him.  Chaz was on regular painkillers and treatment, but the photo he took for his new travel documents showed he was suffering severe jaundice just before he died. Cold, exercise, dehydration, and stress are all known to worsen symptoms of sickle cell. A British Airways spokesperson said: Weaposre saddened to hear that one of our customers has passed away and our thoughts are with his friends and family at this dficult time. Airlines are required by law to ensure that all documents presented for travel are valid. While our airport team did what they could to help Mr Powell, unfortunately the photo page of his passport was so badly damaged it could no longer be regarded as a valid travel document. title: mcdonalds supply chain issue leads
story: McDonald’s supply chain issue leads to shortages and stripped back Big TastyMcDonalds says it is working hard to resolve supply chain issues which have meant a shortage of tomatoes across its UK outlets and resulted in a modied version of the Big Tasty burgerMcDonalds has been hit by supply chain issues Image: NurPhoto PA ImagesByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Mar |commentsMcDonaldaposs has been hit with a tomato shortage, meaning its Big Tasty has had to be modied.Branches of the fast food chain across the UK are affected, with the popular burger having to be served with just one slice of tomato rather than two. The franchise said it is working hard to resolve this issue as quickly as possible. A spokesperson said: “We are currently experiencing a shortage in our supply of tomatoes. As a result, the Big Tasty and the Big Tasty with Bacon are being served with one slice of tomato rather than two. We apologise for any inconvenience, and thank our customers for their patience.  The Big Tasty consists of a large, thick patty topped with Emmental cheese tomato, lettuce, slivered onions and bacon as an option. Itaposs been a huge hit among fast food fans but is only available for a limited amount of time each year - often just a few weeks at a time. It has previously left so many customers wondering why it isnapost always on the menu that last year McDonaldaposs actually put up an explanation on its website.  A statement said: Unfortunately, though itaposs a customer favourite, weaposre unable to offer the Big Tasty all year round because of the limited capacity in our kitchens. If we offered it all year, we wouldnapost have the space to grill the other promotional burgers which are also super popular. But always keep your eyes peeled, Big Tasty fans. Duchess of Cambridge are midway through their Caribbean tour having visited both Belize and Jamaica. And three people eager to track their progress on their travels are their three children Prince George, Princess Charlotte and Prince Louis.The youngsters have not joined their mum and dad on the tour and instead have stayed at home.But at a reception on Monday, Prince William revealed the sweet way that their children have been keeping up with them - and it appears George is in charge of it.William explained that George has been sticking pins in a world map of each of the destinations his parents have visited and then sharing the information with both Charlotte and Louis.  He said: We let them know where we are and he finds us on the map and puts a pin in it and shares with the others.William and Kate are currently on the second day of their stay in Jamaica and have so far held a meeting with the countryaposs Prime Minister. title: uk weather forecast sweltering 20c
story: UK weather forecast: Sweltering C high today and hot flush all the way to weekendThe Met Office is predicting that temperatures could again peak at C on Thursday, for the third day in a row, making the country hotter than Spanish holiday island LanzaroteTemperatures are expected to reach C again on Thursday Image: Liverpool EchoByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Mar |comments Brits are set to bask in a third straight day of C temperatures on Thursday and the scorching weather is expected to carry on into the weekend.After an icy start to March, spring has clearly arrived with sunshine and blue skies up and down the country.Once again the mercury hit C on Wednesday and the hotter than average temperatures are expected to continue for the coming days with the Met Office estimating they are as much as C above the norm for the time of year.The sunshine is thanks to a high pressure system that is sitting over the UK having moved in from the continent giving the country temperatures higher than many southern European holiday hotspots. On Thursday more C heat means that the UK will be warmer than the Spanish holiday island of Lanzarote. Like Wednesday the day will start cold before the sunshine arrives.  “This settled spell of spring sunshine carries on for the rest of the week and beyond, Met Office forecaster Aidan McGivern said. “With clear skies expected tonight temperatures will fall away and a few mist and fog patches could form in one or two spots. They will be fairly isolated and most likely in parts of eastern England for example like recent nights with temperatures dipping away as well. A touch of frost in places as we start off Thursday. Frost free Western Isles, parts of Northern Ireland where it will turn cloudier through the night, perhaps one or two showers into the Western Isles.” Air from the Atlantic is bringing cloudier skies for the north west of Scotland and spots of rain but the high pressure is dominant over the UK meaning warm weather for most.  Mr McGivern continued: On the whole after a chilly start. Much of the UK still basking in that warm March sunshine and temperatures similar across England and Wales to recent days C to C, could squeeze a C in Cambridgeshire for example. Then for Friday there is more of the same eventemperatures are fractionally lower. “Plenty more, well, fine weather to come ... blue skies across the board virtually just one exception there for Shetland, Orkney, thicker clouds, a few drizzly showers at time but where largely dry, said Mr McGivern. For the vast majority dry once againand those temperatures are responding. Technically down a degree or so compared to the last couple of days but with light winds and sunshine I doubt it will be that noticeable. And really those temperatures in place are C perhaps C above average so very warm for the time of year. UK forecast for the next  days Rather cloudy in the northwest, where mostly dry and sunny Today: Early fog patches quickly clearing to leave another warm day with plenty of sunshine for most. Very isolated afternoon showers may develop in the north, more likely over eastern Scotland. Cloudier in the northwest with some light rain at times. Tonight: Rather cloudy for parts of Scotland and Northern Ireland, especially the far north and northwest where a little light rain. Clear where with patchy frost and a few fog patches. Friday: Again dry and warm with sunny spells for many although cloudier in the far northwest. One or two isolated afternoon showers may develop across northern England and southeastern Northern Ireland. Outlook for Saturday to Monday: Mainly settled with light winds and warm sunny spells cloudier in the far north with occasional light rain. Early mist fog patches in places, clearning inland but lingering near some coasts. story: Double jabbed aspiring model, , loses BOTH legs in harrowing Covid battleClaire Bridges from Tampa, Florida, who was born with a congenital heart condition, was also diagnosed with myocarditis, rhabdomyolysis, mild pneumonia, cyanosis and acidosisClaire Bridges lost her legs due to complications from Covid-ByCarly BassSamantha Mordi:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments An aspiring model has been dubbed a warrior by her family after losing both her legs from Covid- complications.Claire Bridges had several emergency operations and a stint on le support, but sadly her legs still couldnapost be saved after they suffered irreversible muscle damage. The -year-old, from Tampa, Florida, was admitted to Tampa General hospital in January this year and her condition started to deteriorate rapidly over a two week period due to organ failure.Claire, who was born with a congenital heart condition, was also diagnosed with myocarditis, rhabdomyolysis, mild pneumonia, cyanosis and acidosis, Yahoo News reports.She was given a TandemHeart – which helps to send a steady supply of oxygenated blood to organs – and hours after that was placed on continuous dialysis because of her failing kidneys. As the complications worsened, so did the condition in her leg so doctors performed a fasciotomy to relieve the swelling and pressure. Despite trying to save her legs, the damage was too severe and irreversible, her dad Wayne Bridges revealed. In February Ms Bridges, who is vaccinated, had both legs cut off above the knee. She wasnapost getting circulation to her legs and, because of that, there was a lot of muscle damage, her best friend Heather Valdes told WTVT, Newsweek reported. Doctors also discovered she was bleeding internally resulting in an emergency blood transfusion.They found a very rare lesion in the first part of the small intestines that had ruptured, her dad revealed on Facebook. Luckily they were able to fix it and stop the bleeding. Despite the le-changing event, Ms Bridges remained positive according to family and friends who described her as an amazing young woman and a warrior. Her dad Wayne has detailed his daughteraposs journey on Facebook and revealed on March  that she was finally able to sit up herself for the first time since January. Two months to the day this all started and Claire, for the first time sat up by herself, he wrote on Facebook. It may not seem like a lot, but for this Warrior itaposs a major victory! And for this victory, it looks like our Warrior girl is coming home to her momaposs house today for the rehab phase of her journey. This week, Claire was released from hospital in time for her st birthday. She is very happy to be home around family and friends, Mr Bridges told Newsweek. Itaposs been mentally, emotionally taxing but weaposre hopeful now. She is still facing more challenges but we are focused on having her home. Mr Bridges said his daughter will require ongoing rehab with physical and occupational therapy. She will also need to prepare for prosthetic legs. Mr Bridges set up a GoFundMe page for his daughter with hopes to raise £, which will go towards Claireaposs medical and ongoing recovery expenses. I am so proud of you and inspired by you. You have overcome more in two months than any of us could imagine in a letime, Mr Bridges wrote in a touching tribute on Facebook. You will be climbing again before you know it. OBrien has now been sentenced to a juvenile facilityTravis O’Brien, now , has been sentenced to a juvenile facilityByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Mar A -year-old boy and a -year-old pal armed with an AK- held a  minute shoot-out with police in Florida. Travis O’Brien, now , has been sentenced to a juvenile facility after firing at police in June last year along with his teen accomplice Nicole Jackson. The pair had broken out of a local children’s home and had entered a house in Volusia County when the gun fight started.Defence lawyer Jeff Deen told WESH-TV : “He’s a little tiny, little boy and he got into a big mess.“He wasn’t in control of his situation and he can’t understand some of the things that we understand.” The youngster pleaded no contest to charges of burglary, criminal mischief and attempted murder of law enforcement officers, and was remanded to a maximum-risk assessment programme followed by a conditional release.  The “Bonnie and Clyde” duo had escaped from Florida United Methodist Children’s Home and were hiding in an empty home in nearby Enterprise on June . Police arrived after reports of a break-in at the property and began to be fired at by the two children. The gun battle continued for  minutes with an officer heard saying on a viral video at one point that Jackson was “re-racking”. The officer said: “Female has a shotgun in her hand, stand by.” He is then heard shouting “put the gun down now” and then shooting can be heard.  “They’re shooting on me,” the officer then said. “Hold the air. I’m code . She’s re-racking a round inside the shotgun.” The dispatcher replies: “Let’s not engage them anymore. “Let’s not challenge them.” But the officer said: “She’s racked a round in the shotgun. The window’s busted on the patio side. If she comes out she’s going to have the shotgun.” Then moments later Jackson came out of the house with gun and was shot - with her screams heard in video footage. “I think the female’s down,” an officer said. “Call in the units. Female’s on the ground behind the car.”  The footage then shows the boy surrendering and being taken into custody. Jackson was taken to hospital with le threatening injuries after being shot in the chest and arm but she recovered after surgery. She is yet to be sentenced for her involvement in the incident. Meanwhile, a couple, Shauna and Dan Willis, have reportedly offered to adopt Jackson after talking to her by phone from her jail.“We just have good intentions in mind for her. story: Jeffrey Epsteins Caribbean properties including Paedophile Island goes up for saleJeffrey Epsteins Caribbean properties including infamous Paedophile Island where Prince Andrew is claimed to have stayed goes up for saleSituated in the US Virgin Islands, Great St James and Little St James islands have been put on the market by Epsteins estateByChristopher BucktinUnited States Editor:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar The Caribbean island on which Prince Andrew is claimed to have visited his paedophile pal Jeffrey Epstein has gone on sale. Two properties that were once at the centre of the disgraced financieraposs real estate portfolio are being listed for £ million. Situated in the US Virgin Islands, Great St James and Little St James islands have been put on the market by Epsteinaposs estate. According to reports in the US, money from their sale will help fund outstanding lawsuits filed by the late sex offenderaposs victims and the costs of running the properties. Little St James is where the Duke of Yorkaposs sex accuser Virginia Giuffre claimed in court he took part in a nine girl orgy with Epstein. The Prince vehemently denied her claims.  Ms Giuffre wrote in evidence to a Florida Court on January , : The third time I had sex with Andy was in an orgy on Epstein’s private island in the US Virgin Islands. I was around  at the time. Epstein, Andy, approximately eight other young girls, and I had sex together. The other girls all seemed and appeared to be under the age of  and didn’t really speak English. Ms Giuffre added Epstein “laughed about the fact they couldn’t really communicate, saying that they are the ‘easiest’ girls to get along with”. The court filings were made in a civil defamation lawsuit filed by Ms Giuffre against since-convicted child sex trafficker Ghislaine Maxwell. The mum-of-three would later go on to sue Andrew in August  for sex abuse in New York. The case was settled last month with a reported £ million out of court settlement paid to Ms Giuffre by the royal. Before his jail cell suicide in August , Epstein once described the United States Virgin Islands as my favourite place to be. It became a haven for him and his associates, Epsteinaposs victims claim to have been abused there. The financieraposs private aposLolita Expressapos jet would fly him to St Thomasaposs international airport, where he would board a helicopter that flew him to his Little St. James and Great St. James islands. Once there, he was known to entertain famous friends and, his accusers have claimed in court filings, trafficked underage girls for sex. Epstein arrived in the Virgin Islands in , when he paid £ million for Little St. James, a roughly -acre island. He called it Little St Jeffaposs. In , he bought the larger Great St. James for £. million.  Over the years, he spent millions more developing the islands, including building a villa with a library, a Japanese bathhouse and a movie theatre. When he was there, he cultivated close ties to the islandsapos political and financial elite. He once employed a governoraposs we. Epstein hired an architecture firm owned by the same governoraposs uncle. He also donated money, sponsored scholarships and even gave dozens of computers to give away. A lawsuit filed by prosecutors in the US Virgin Islands two years ago alleged Epstein used his two secluded islands to engage in a nearly two-decade conspiracy to traffic and abuse girls as young as  years old.  According to the complaint, he and others organised a search party to catch a -year-old victim trying to swim away and kept her passport to keep her captive. From  to , Epstein and his aides, among them Ghislaine Maxwell, flew girls from other countries to the Virgin Islands on the multimillionaireaposs private plane. Epstein, , killed himself in a New York federal jail in August  while awaiting trial on sex trafficking charges. Maxwell, , was convicted in December of sex trafficking and other charges for helping Epstein sexually abuse multiple teenage girls from  to . story: First female US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright dies after cancer battleFormer US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright was today remembered as not only a trailblazer for women in police but as a loving mother, grandmother, sister, aunt, and friend - Former United States Secretary of State Madeleine Albright gestures after speaking on the second day of the Democratic National Convention at the Wells Fargo Center in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, USA,  July  Former US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright died at the age of  today Image: TANNEN MAURY EPA-EFE REX ShutterstockByChristopher BucktinUnited States Editor:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsMadeleine Albright, the first woman US secretary of state, has died after battling cancer. She was . Before her death, Albright helped steer Western foreign policy in the aftermath of the Cold War. Her death was confirmed by her family and in an email to staff of the Albright Stonebridge Group, a global strategy firm founded by her. We are heartbroken to announce that Dr Madeleine K Albright, the th US Secretary of State and the first woman to hold that position, passed away earlier today, the statement read. The family confirmed her cause of death was cancer and said she was surrounded by family and friends when she passed.  We have lost a loving mother, grandmother, sister, aunt, and friend, the statement continued. The politician came to the States from Prague as a refugee in . President Bill Clinton named Albright U.S. ambassador to the United Nations shortly after he was inaugurated in  and nominated her as secretary of state three years later. She served in the post for four years, promoting the expansion of NATO and military intervention in Kosovo.  She grew to become the face of US foreign policy in the decade between the end of the Cold War and the War on Terror triggered by the September ,  attacks. In , then-President Barack Obama her the Medal of Freedom, the countryaposs highest civilian honour. Two years ago, Albright described how she had a trick to make sure her position was made clear in a foreign policy arena dominated by men. Mona Route, , was let go from her server job at an airport in Melbourne, Australia, when Covid- hit in March , and the newfound time on her hands left her feeling so bored, the Daily Star reports. With nothing  to do, Mona decided to take up baking as a hobby to pass the time and soon found herself trying out experimental dessert recipes - which eventually led her to start her own cookie business. title: your coffee order could determine
story: Your coffee order could determine whether youre selfish or fun, expert saysA human behavioural expert has claimed he can determine someones personality just from looking at their go-to coffee order - but what does yours say about you Does your coffee order make you no-nonsense or carefree  Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsIf you like a cup of coffee, you probably have a go-to order that you revisit time and time again when you walk into your local coffee shop.But did you know that every time you reel off that order, youaposre giving away secrets about your personality  Thataposs the claim made by Darren Stanton, a human behavioural expert, former police detective, and psychologist, who says thereaposs a deeper meaning behind every one of our coffee orders. Darren spoke to Delish about what each type of coffee means for the person who drinks it - so what does your favourite say about you Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Black coffee A black coffee, or Americano, is one of the easiest things to order at any coffee house, as youaposll be able to skip the questions about which type of milk youaposd prefer. And according to Darren,you like the no-nonsense approach of a black coffee, then youaposre probably someone who is determined, focused, and driven. But the expert says the ambition of a black coffee drinker can also drive them to be self-sufficient and empowered - meaning they can border on having a selfish mentality. Latte Although coffee gives us a caffeine hit, donapost expect latte drinkers to be hyperactive - as theyaposre actually the most laidback of all coffee drinkers, according to Darren.  The behavioural expert claims a latte lover is likely to be a middle-of-the-road type that doesnapost like taking risks. He added: Latte drinkers tend to be mild-mannered, agreeable, happy to go with the flow. They just want something simple to drink without complication. Cappuccino Frothier than a latte, the cappuccino is a more adventurous drink - and it makes those who drink it more fun, too. Darren says these coffee fans arenapost afraid of unknown territory, and are therefore open-minded and always up for trying something new. Espresso Much like their black coffee drinking friends, anyone who walks into a coffee shop and dares to order a single or double shot of espresso is likely a no-nonsense, straight-talking type of person, according to Darren.  The expert says ordering an espresso illustrates someone is adventurous and powerful and strong in character - and theyaposre probably also the type of person to order a shot of whiskey or rum in a pub. Mocha Blending the sophistication of coffee with the sweetness of chocolate, the mocha is probably the cutest of all coffees. Darren believes anyone who enjoys a mocha is very extroverted, outgoing, flamboyant, and potentially quite loud - and friends probably call them the le of the party. Flat white If mochas indicate carefree people, then flat white drinkers are the complete opposite - as Darren says this drink is most commonly enjoyed by coffee snobs who like the acquired taste of the strong drink. He said: The flat white is a much stronger coffee and a more acquired taste. People who order flat whites could perhaps be loners. Theyaposd stand by their opinions no matter what and have clear views on particularly spiky subjects. The expert also has similar opinions about cortado drinkers, who are intelligent but also enjoy sticking to the rules and havin structure in their lives. Syrups For those of us who like an extra taste of something sweet in our coffee, Darren says youaposre most likely to be trustworthy and creative - as you like to switch things up with your coffee order. The expert believes those who put syrup in coffee are happy to experiment with new flavours. title: five ancient tombs discovered egypt
story: Five ancient tombs discovered in Egypt - and theyre at least , years oldThe well-preserved tombs, thought to be at least , years old, were unearthed in Saqqara, outside Cairo and belong to some of the era’s top officials, including court advisers and priests" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _Egypt-unveils-five-ancient-tombs-in-Saqqara-necropolis.jpg" width"" "" The tombs were unearthed in Saqqara, an acropolis outside Cairo Image: Anadolu Agency via Getty ImagesBySam TrueloveNews reporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsFive ancient tombs thought to be at least , years old have been discovered in Egypt. The well-preserved graves, dating to the Old Kingdom and the First Intermediate Period, were unearthed in Saqqara, an acropolis outside Cairo, last week. The Egyptian Ministry of Tourism and Antiquities has since confirmed that the tombs belonged to some of the era’s top officials, including court advisers and priests. Pictures taken by photographers show the inside of the tombs, which boast elaborately painted walls. Itaposs reported the chambers contained over  sarcophagi, toys, wooden boats, masks and more artefacts.Mostafa Waziri, Secretary General of the Supreme Council of Antiquities, spoke outside one of the tombs, as seen on the Egyptian Ministry of Tourism and Antiquities Facebook page.  He said: From one oaposclock in the morning, we are proud that this discovery was made by pure Egyptian hands. We are talking about a grave of someone called Hino. Talking about an old country. Weaposre talking about , years, patterns and colours at its finest.  Today they gonna tease the whole world. And they say this discovery was done by pure Egyptian hands. Although there are very many mission that went to Saqqara area, but it was a great sadness and praise to God that we discover five graves that we announce today to amaze the world and the work did not stop. Wait for more, god willing.The news comes after last week it was revealed hidden voids in the Great Pyramid of Giza could be the secret chambers of a pharaohaposs tomb. A high-powered scan revealed there are two hidden voids inside the largest man-made pyramid on Earth and now archaeologists are planning to get a better look inside with better technology.The largest of the two voids is  feet long and  feet wide. Archaeologists are hoping new scans will uncover what the mysterious voids were used for.Researchers believe the best case scenario would be the uncovering of the hidden burial chamber of pharaoh Khufu, who reigned over Egypt from  BC to  BC, and was the man the pyramid was built for.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Pyramids" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: meghan markles ally blasts palace
story: Meghan Markles ally blasts palace as he hits out at Will and Kate in JamaicaMeghan Markles close ally blasted the Palace for the "imagery" presented in the latest pictures of Prince William and Kate Middleton taken during their tour in JamaicaThe Duke and Duchess of Cambridge are on their week-long tour of the Caribbean - their first joint overseas trip since the start of the pandemic Image: Chris Jackson Pool via REUTERSByLucy WilliamsonReporter:,  Mar |commentsMeghan Markleaposs close friend Omid Scobie has said said the lack of ersity in the Palace is to blame for certain imagery depicted in pictures of the Cambridgeaposs greeting fans in Jamaica.Scobie, best known for co-authoring the biography Finding Freedom which focuses on the family le of Meghan Markle and Prince Harry, blasted the Palace for not avoiding certain imagery in the highly-anticipated pictures of Prince William and Kate Middleton.The images showed them laughing and joking with young Jamaicans, watching the football match from behind a fence. Omid tweeted: I do wonder what the hell palace organisers were thinking with some of yesterdayaposs photo moments.  The planning and recon that goes into every step of these engagements is next level, so how did no one think to avoid certain imagery apos This is why ersity on a team matters. But royal experts quickly commented that separate photos showed England footballer Raheem Sterling, who was born on the island, posing for similar shots with the fans after appearing on the pitch with the royals yesterday.  Wider shots also showed the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge smiling, laughing and shaking hands with their supporters through the fence after the match. Royal editor and host of the Pod Save The Queen podcast Russell Myers posted: For all the commentary from tightly cropped pictures of William and Kate saying hello and shaking hands to people standing behind a metal fence, which was actually on a football field after a game, here is Raheem Sterling in the same place doing the same thing yesterday.apos He added: I donapost know where to start with this…. Incredibly disappointing manipulation and absolute distortion of facts, supplemented by a completely perverse take which I still canapost get my head around.  Omidaposs comments come as the Cambridgeaposs posed for smiling selfies and were met with chants of we love you, we love you on their first day in Jamaica, on a tour to mark the Queenaposs Platinum Jubilee. The royals also met the Jamaican bobsleigh team, who finished th in the recent Winter Olympics, on their week-long tour that will next see them in the Bahamas.  But it comes as the Cambridgeaposs, on arrival in Jamaica were met by a much-publicised demonstration urging the monarchy to pay reparations for slavery, and there have been calls from politicians for the country to drop the Queen as head of state and become a republic. The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge’s visit to Jamaica has given the nation the opportunity address “unresolved” issues, Prime Minister Andrew Holness has told the couple.  As he welcomed the couple before sitting down for talks, Mr Holness said: “There are issues here which are, as you would know, unresolved but your presence gives an opportunity for those issues to be placed in context, put front and centre and to be addressed in as bestas we can. “But Jamaica is, as you would see, a country that is very proud of our history, very proud of what we have achieved. “And we’re moving on and we intend to attain in short order our development goals and fulfil our true ambitions and destiny as an independent, developed, prosperous country.” Buckingham Palace declined to comment on Omid Scobieaposs claims.
